conclusion: Analyze each part of the ion implantation process: velocity selector, magnetic analyzer, and deflection system.
In the velocity selector, ions are subjected to both an electric field E and a uniform magnetic field B that are perpendicular to each other and to the direction of the ion's motion.
The electric field accelerates the ions, and the magnetic field causes the ions to follow a circular path due to the Lorentz force.
The radius of the circular path of the ions can be determined using the equation R = mv/qB.
Variables: m is the mass of the ion, v is the velocity of the ion, q is the charge of the ion, B is the magnetic field strength.
To find the velocity v, consider the acceleration from the electric field: F_E = qE and d^2x/dt^2 = qE/m.
Integrating twice to find v: v = sqrt(2qEL/m).
The radius R of the circular path in the velocity selector becomes R = sqrt(2mEL/qB).
In the magnetic analyzer, the ions with the correct velocity v will pass through the aperture at one end (M or N) without deviating significantly.
The magnetic field B causes these ions to move in a circular path with a larger radius compared to the velocity selector.
The charge-to-mass ratio q/m can be found from the radius of curvature in the magnetic analyzer: m/q = v/BR.
Using the expression for v: m/q = sqrt(2qEL/m)/BR.
The velocity v of the ions after passing through the velocity selector is v = sqrt(2qEL/m).
The charge-to-mass ratio q/m of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer is q/m = sqrt(B^2 R^2/2EL).
